Affect Characteristics Implied by the OU Process

Source: vignettes/characteristics.Rmd
characteristics.Rmd
library(affectOU)

Modelling affect with the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) process implies affect dynamics are characterized by several distinct features. This vignette demonstrates each feature visually. For mathematical definitions of the quantities shown here, see stability(), stationary(), and relaxation().

1. Mean Reversion

After perturbations, affect returns toward its baseline Œº\mu at a rate determined by Œ∏\theta (for stable, unidimensional systems). High Œ∏\theta indicates rapid regulation; low Œ∏\theta indicates emotional inertia.

Show code 
model <- affectOU(theta = diag(c(5.0, 0.5)), initial_state = 3)
sim <- simulate(model, seed = 123, stop = 20)
plot(sim,
  by_dim = FALSE,
  main = "Mean Reversion Depends on Œ∏",
  sub = c("Fast Regulation (Œ∏ = 5.0)", "Slow Regulation (Œ∏ = 0.5)")
)

2. Perturbation Persistence

The relaxation time œÑ=1/Œ∏\tau = 1/\theta is the characteristic time scale of the OU process‚Äîthe time for the expected deviation to shrink to 1/e‚âà36.8%1/e \approx 36.8\%. The half-life t1/2=ln2‚ãÖœÑt_{1/2} = \ln 2 \cdot \tau marks the 50% point. Effects decay exponentially: at two œÑ\tau, about 13.5% remains; at three œÑ\tau, about 5%.

model <- affectOU(theta = 0.5, mu = 0, gamma = 1)
relaxation(model)
#> 
#> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Relaxation time of 1D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ
#> 
#> Half-life (t‚ÇÅ/‚ÇÇ): 1.386 time units
#> Relaxation time (œÑ): 2 time units
#> 
#> Time for perturbation to decay to:
#>      50%     37%     14%      5%      1%
#>    1.386   2.000   4.000   6.000  10.000
Show code 
# Simulate with more time points for accurate ACF
sim <- simulate(model, stop = 10000, dt = 0.01, save_at = 0.01)
plot(sim, type = "acf", lag.max = 10)

The ACF equals 1/e1/e at the relaxation time and 0.50.5 at the half-life. Slow regulation means longer persistence and higher autocorrelation. See relaxation() for more details on this concept and its interpretations.

3. Reactivity

The parameter Œ≥\gamma controls the magnitude of random perturbations‚Äîemotional reactivity to environmental fluctuations.

Show code 
model <- affectOU(theta = 0.5, mu = 0, gamma = diag(c(0.3, 1.5)))
sim <- simulate(model, seed = 456, stop = 20)
plot(sim,
  by_dim = FALSE,
  sub = c("Low Reactivity (Œ≥ = 0.3)", "High Reactivity (Œ≥ = 1.5)"),
  main = "Effect of Reactivity on Fluctuation Magnitude", ylim = c(-4, 4)
)

Higher Œ≥\gamma produces larger fluctuations around the attractor.

4. Stability Regimes

Univariate

The sign of Œ∏\theta determines qualitative behaviour:

  • Œ∏>0\theta > 0: Stable. Mean-reverting around Œº\mu. Affect fluctuates within a bounded range.
  • Œ∏‚âà0\theta \approx 0: Random walk. No attractor; variance grows over time. Affect drifts without returning.
  • Œ∏<0\theta < 0: Unstable. Exponential divergence from Œº\mu. Small perturbations amplify.
Show code 
model <- affectOU(theta = diag(c(0.5, 0.01, -0.3)))
sim <- simulate(model, stop = 100, seed = 43)
plot(sim,
  ylim = c(-10, 10), by_dim = FALSE,
  main = "Affect Dynamics of Different Stability Regimes",
  sub = c("Œ∏ > 0 (stable)", "Œ∏ ‚âà 0 (random walk)", "Œ∏ < 0 (unstable)")
)

Multivariate

For multiple dimensions, stability depends on the eigenvalues of ùöØ\boldsymbol{\Theta}. Three cases arise:

  • Real positive eigenvalues: Smooth exponential decay toward ùõç\boldsymbol{\mu}. All dimensions settle without oscillation.
  • Complex eigenvalues with positive real parts: Damped oscillations. Dimensions rotate around ùõç\boldsymbol{\mu} in the phase space, spiralling inward. This can represent cyclical affect patterns.
  • Any eigenvalue with zero or negative real part: The system is non-stationary. Affect diverges over time ‚Äì either drifting monotonically or oscillating with growing amplitude, depending on whether the eigenvalues are real or complex.
Show code 
# Real eigenvalues: smooth decay
theta_real <- matrix(c(0.5, 0.1, 0.1, 0.5), 2, byrow = TRUE)
eigen(theta_real)$values
#> [1] 0.6 0.4

# Complex eigenvalues: oscillatory decay
theta_complex <- matrix(c(0.5, -0.4, 0.4, 0.5), 2)
eigen(theta_complex)$values
#> [1] 0.5+0.4i 0.5-0.4i
seed <- 123
sim_real <- simulate(
  affectOU(theta = theta_real, mu = 0, sigma = .1),
  stop = 50, seed = seed
)
sim_complex <- simulate(
  affectOU(theta = theta_complex, mu = 0, sigma = .1),
  stop = 50, seed = seed
)
plot(sim_real, type = "phase", main = "Real eigenvalues")

plot(sim_complex, type = "phase", main = "Complex eigenvalues")

The oscillatory case shows rotation in the phase space, reflecting the imaginary component of the eigenvalues. For affect dynamics, this could represent alternating patterns between dimensions (e.g., valence and arousal cycling together).

5. Multivariate Coupling

In multivariate models, off-diagonal elements of ùöØ\boldsymbol{\Theta} capture cross-regulation between dimensions.

ùöØ=[Œ∏11Œ∏12Œ∏21Œ∏22]=[self-regulation of dim 1influence of dim 2 on dim 1influence of dim 1 on dim 2self-regulation of dim 2]\boldsymbol{\Theta} = \begin{bmatrix} \theta_{11} & \theta_{12} \\ \theta_{21} & \theta_{22} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \text{self-regulation of dim 1} & \text{influence of dim 2 on dim 1} \\ \text{influence of dim 1 on dim 2} & \text{self-regulation of dim 2} \end{bmatrix}

Show code 
# Dimension 1's deviations from baseline push dimension 2 in the opposite direction
theta_2d <- matrix(c(
  0.5, 0.0,
  2, 0.5
), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE)

model_2d <- affectOU(theta = theta_2d, mu = 0, gamma = 1)
sim_2d <- simulate(model_2d, seed = 102)
plot(sim_2d, by_dim = FALSE, main = "Coupled Trajectories", xlim = c(0, 20))

plot(sim_2d, type = "phase", main = "Phase Portrait")

The positive entry Œ∏21\theta_{21} means that when dimension 1 deviates from its attractor, it pushes dimension 2 in the opposite direction: if dimension 1 is above baseline, dimension 2 is pushed down, and vice versa. This creates interdependent dynamics visible in the phase portrait.

6. Noise Coupling

Off-diagonal elements of ùö™\boldsymbol{\Gamma} create correlated noise between dimensions. This can lead to synchronized fluctuations even in uncoupled systems.

Show code 
# Correlated noise with no cross-regulation
gamma_2d <- matrix(c(
  1, 0.5,
  0.5, 1
), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE)

model_2d <- affectOU(theta = 0.5, mu = 0, gamma = gamma_2d)
sim_2d <- simulate(model_2d, seed = 102)
plot(sim_2d, by_dim = FALSE, main = "Correlated Noise", xlim = c(0, 20))

plot(sim_2d, type = "phase", main = "Phase Portrait")

Summary

Feature Parameter Effect
Mean reversion Œ∏\theta Rate of return to baseline
Perturbation persistence Œ∏\theta Half-life of perturbations
Reactivity Œ≥\gamma Magnitude of fluctuations
Stability sign(Œ∏\theta) / eigenvalues of ùöØ\boldsymbol{\Theta} Stationary vs divergent
Cross-coupling off-diagonal ùöØ\boldsymbol{\Theta} Interdimensional dynamics
Noise coupling off-diagonal ùö™\boldsymbol{\Gamma} Interdimensional dynamics
